This study investigates the susceptibility of DRL policies to small, imperceptible perturbations in the state space, which can cause catastrophic failures. We introduce a novel defense mechanism, Robust Policy Distillation (RPD), which trains a student policy to mimic a teacher ensemble's decisions on both clean and adversarially perturbed states. In simulated robotic control environments, agents trained with RPD maintained over 85% of their original performance under strong attacks, compared to near-total collapse for unprotected agents.
label: AI

text: Data scarcity is a significant bottleneck in developing accurate machine learning models for niche domains, such as manufacturing defect detection. This paper presents a data augmentation strategy using a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (C-GAN) to synthesize high-fidelity, class-conditional images of rare defects. Our C-GAN is trained on a limited dataset to generate realistic new samples of underrepresented fault classes. A classifier trained on a hybrid dataset of original and synthetic images achieved a 12% increase in F1-score and a 15% improvement in recall for the minority class, demonstrating the viability of GAN-based augmentation.
label: AI

text: Accelerating the identification of viable drug candidates is a primary challenge in pharmaceutical research. This work leverages Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to directly learn from the molecular graph structure of chemical compounds, bypassing manual feature engineering. We introduce a graph attention-based model to predict molecule-protein binding affinity, a key indicator of a drug's efficacy. Trained on a large-scale public bioactivity database, our model significantly outperforms traditional machine learning methods and molecular docking simulations, achieving a 20% reduction in mean squared error. This GNN-based approach provides a powerful framework for in-silico screening and lead optimization.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the epigenetic silencing of tumor suppressor genes in tumorigenesis. We focused on the role of histone deacetylases (HDACs), enzymes that remove acetyl groups from histones, leading to chromatin compaction and transcriptional repression. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and gene expression analysis in a model of colorectal cancer, we identified a specific HDAC isoform that is significantly upregulated. Its targeted inhibition via small molecule inhibitors resulted in the re-acetylation of histone H3 at the promoter of a key tumor suppressor gene, restoring its expression and inducing apoptosis in cancer cells. These findings underscore the critical role of aberrant epigenetic modifications in oncogenesis and validate HDACs as promising therapeutic targets.
label: AI

text: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are key post-transcriptional regulators, and their dysregulation is associated with numerous pathologies. This research explored the role of circulating miRNAs as potential non-invasive biomarkers for cardiac fibrosis. Through deep sequencing of plasma samples from fibrotic patients and healthy controls, we identified a distinct miRNA signature, with one specific miRNA, miR-X, consistently upregulated. In vitro functional assays in cardiac fibroblasts confirmed that miR-X directly targets and represses the mRNA of a crucial anti-fibrotic protein. Our results suggest that circulating levels of miR-X correlate with disease severity, positioning it as a promising diagnostic biomarker and a potential therapeutic target for anti-fibrotic therapies.
label: AI

text: The integrity of the genome is constantly challenged by DNA-damaging agents. The Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) pathway is a versatile mechanism for removing a wide range of bulky DNA lesions. This study elucidates the role of a previously uncharacterized protein, XYZ1, in the early stages of damage recognition. Using live-cell imaging and co-immunoprecipitation, we demonstrate that XYZ1 is rapidly recruited to sites of UV-induced DNA damage, where it functions as a scaffold to stabilize the assembly of the core NER pre-incision complex. Depletion of XYZ1 resulted in delayed repair kinetics and increased cellular sensitivity to UV radiation, establishing its critical function in maintaining genomic stability.
label: AI

text: The therapeutic potential of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing is hampered by concerns over off-target mutations. To address this, we have engineered a high-fidelity Cas9 variant through structure-guided protein design. This variant incorporates specific amino acid substitutions that weaken non-specific DNA interactions while preserving on-target recognition. We assessed its activity across multiple human cell lines and genomic loci using unbiased, genome-wide off-target detection methods. The engineered nuclease demonstrated a significant reduction—up to 95%—in off-target editing events compared to wild-type Cas9, without compromising its on-target efficiency. This development represents a critical step towards safer genome editing for clinical applications.
label: AI

text: Misfolded protein accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) activates the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR), a signaling network aimed at restoring homeostasis. However, chronic ER stress can switch the UPR to a pro-apoptotic program. This study investigates the contribution of the PERK signaling branch of the UPR to neuronal cell death in a model of neurodegeneration. We demonstrate that sustained PERK activation leads to the upregulation of the transcription factor CHOP, which subsequently induces the apoptotic cascade. Pharmacological inhibition of the PERK pathway, downstream of the initial stress sensor, successfully attenuated CHOP expression and protected neurons from apoptosis, without altering the overall load of misfolded protein aggregates.
label: AI

text: This study introduces a novel deep learning framework for predicting protein-ligand binding affinity, a critical step in computational drug discovery. By leveraging graph convolutional networks and attention mechanisms, our model learns intricate 3D structural and chemical features directly from protein-ligand complex data. Tested on the PDBbind benchmark dataset, the model achieved a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.85, outperforming existing state-of-the-art scoring functions. The attention mechanism successfully highlighted key interacting residues, providing interpretability for lead optimization. This approach significantly enhances the accuracy and speed of virtual screening, promising to accelerate the identification of potent drug candidates.
label: AI

text: We address the challenge of annotating non-coding variants from whole-genome sequencing data by developing a machine learning model that integrates diverse genomic features. Our method combines sequence conservation scores, epigenetic marks from the ENCODE project, and 3D chromatin interaction data to predict the regulatory potential of intergenic and intronic single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The model, trained on a curated set of known causal regulatory variants, demonstrated a high area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC = 0.92) in cross-validation. Application of this tool to a cohort of patients with autoimmune disease identified several high-impact non-coding variants within enhancer regions of immune-related genes.
label: AI

text: Reconstructing accurate phylogenies from large-scale genomic data is often hampered by conflicting signals among genes and computational limitations. We present a novel quartet-based algorithm that efficiently processes thousands of gene alignments to infer a species tree. By decomposing the problem into four-taxon subproblems and using a fast coalescent-aware method to assemble the final tree, our approach mitigates issues of long-branch attraction and incomplete lineage sorting. Applied to a dataset of 1,200 vertebrate genomes, the method produced a highly resolved phylogeny consistent with established fossil records, yet completed the analysis in a fraction of the time required by concatenation-based approaches.
label: AI

text: The analysis of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) data is confounded by technical noise and high dimensionality. Here, we propose a variational autoencoder-based method for data denoising, imputation, and visualization. Our model learns a latent representation of the cellular state that effectively separates biological variation from technical artifacts. When applied to a mixture of cell lines and primary tumor samples, our approach not only improved the clustering of distinct cell types but also accurately inferred developmental trajectories. This integrated tool provides a robust framework for extracting meaningful biological insights from complex and sparse scRNA-seq datasets, facilitating deeper understanding of cellular heterogeneity.
label: AI

text: This research presents a new computational pipeline for the functional and taxonomic analysis of shotgun metagenomic data from environmental samples. The pipeline integrates rapid, k-mer based taxonomic classification with a novel protein-domain-centric approach for functional profiling, bypassing the need for computationally expensive sequence assembly. We validated the pipeline on synthetic microbial communities, demonstrating superior accuracy in quantifying both species abundance and metabolic pathway potential compared to existing methods. Application to soil samples from an agricultural chronosequence revealed distinct shifts in nitrogen cycling pathways correlated with land-use intensity, showcasing the pipeline's utility in ecological studies.
label: AI

text: This study analyzes the economic viability and policy drivers of utility-scale photovoltaic (PV) adoption across emerging economies. Using a longitudinal dataset from 2010-2022, we correlate the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) for solar projects with national policy instruments, including feed-in tariffs, tax incentives, and streamlined permitting processes. Our regression analysis reveals that strong, consistent policy support is the primary determinant in reducing LCOE and accelerating grid parity. Findings indicate that for every 10% increase in policy stability scores, the LCOE decreases by an average of 6.5%, underscoring the critical role of government intervention in de-risking investments.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the operational stability of tandem perovskite-on-silicon solar cells, a promising next-generation photovoltaic technology. We subjected encapsulated devices to accelerated degradation testing, including damp-heat and thermal cycling, while monitoring performance via in-situ photoluminescence spectroscopy. Our results demonstrate that a novel interfacial layer of quantum dots effectively passivates defects and suppresses ion migration, a key failure mechanism. The modified cells retained 95% of their initial 29.8% power conversion efficiency after 1,000 hours of continuous stress, representing a significant advancement toward the commercial feasibility of ultra-high-efficiency perovskite-based photovoltaics.
label: AI

text: The intermittency of solar and wind power presents a significant challenge to grid stability. This paper models the integration of grid-scale Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) to mitigate frequency deviations in a power system with high renewable penetration. Using a dynamic simulation of a modified IEEE 39-bus test system, we evaluate the efficacy of various BESS control strategies in providing ancillary services. The results show that a distributed BESS network with predictive state-of-charge management can reduce frequency containment reserve requirements from conventional generators by over 60%, enhancing grid resilience and enabling deeper decarbonization of the electricity sector.
label: AI

text: This paper assesses the ecological impact of onshore wind farm development on avian biodiversity and habitat fragmentation. Through a multi-year comparative field study utilizing GPS telemetry on raptor populations and remote sensing data, we analyzed flight patterns and land-use changes in both turbine-dense and control areas. The study reveals a significant avoidance behavior in multiple raptor species, leading to functional habitat loss extending beyond the physical footprint of the turbines. We conclude that strategic micrositing, informed by detailed pre-construction ecological surveys and the implementation of smart curtailment systems, is essential to mitigate adverse impacts on sensitive wildlife.
label: AI

text: This study examines the socio-political factors influencing public acceptance of geothermal energy projects in rural communities. Employing a mixed-methods approach combining household surveys (n=480) and semi-structured interviews with local stakeholders, we analyze perceptions of risk, trust in developers, and distributive justice. Findings indicate that community opposition is driven less by technical concerns and more by procedural inequities, such as a lack of transparent communication and non-inclusive decision-making processes. The research highlights that fostering early, sustained community engagement and ensuring equitable benefit-sharing are paramount for gaining the social license required for successful project implementation.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the application of unsupervised machine learning models for real-time anomaly detection within Industrial Control Systems (ICS). Traditional signature-based intrusion detection systems often fail to identify novel, zero-day attacks targeting SCADA networks. We propose a framework utilizing a variational autoencoder (VAE) to learn the normal operational baseline from high-dimensional sensor data. Deviations from this learned normality are flagged as potential intrusions. The model is evaluated on a simulated power grid dataset, demonstrating high efficacy in detecting stealthy manipulation attacks. We also explore the model's resilience against adversarial inputs, highlighting the critical need for robust AI in securing critical infrastructure.
label: AI

text: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices presents a significant security challenge due to inherent resource constraints, including limited processing power, memory, and energy. This study examines the feasibility of implementing lightweight cryptographic primitives and secure boot mechanisms on low-power microcontrollers. We present a novel, energy-efficient authentication protocol designed for heterogeneous IoT ecosystems. Through empirical analysis, we demonstrate that our protocol provides robust security against common threats, such as device impersonation, while imposing minimal computational overhead. Our findings contribute to a framework for secure device lifecycle management, mitigating the risk of large-scale botnet conscription.
label: AI

text: This paper evaluates the efficacy of gamified security awareness training in mitigating employee susceptibility to phishing attacks. While traditional training methods show limited long-term effectiveness, this study hypothesizes that incorporating game mechanics—such as points and immediate feedback—can enhance user engagement and knowledge retention. We conducted a longitudinal study within a corporate environment, comparing a gamified training module against a conventional approach. Results indicate a statistically significant reduction in click-through rates on simulated phishing emails for the gamified group. The findings suggest that gamification can effectively counteract cognitive biases exploited by attackers, fostering a more resilient security culture.
label: AI

text: The advent of fault-tolerant quantum computers poses an existential threat to currently deployed public-key cryptography, including RSA and ECC. In response, the field of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) has emerged, developing algorithms resistant to both classical and quantum attacks. This article analyzes the practical challenges of migrating global digital infrastructure to PQC standards. We examine the performance overhead of leading PQC candidates, such as lattice-based schemes, and discuss the complexities of integration into existing protocols and public-key infrastructures (PKI). We argue that achieving "cryptographic agility" is paramount, proposing a hybrid implementation model to facilitate a phased and secure transition.
label: AI

text: Modern software development heavily relies on third-party and open-source components, creating a complex and often opaque software supply chain susceptible to compromise. This research explores the role of the Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) as a foundational tool for enhancing transparency and proactive vulnerability management. We present a methodology for automatically generating and analyzing SBOMs throughout the CI/CD pipeline. By mapping component dependencies against known vulnerability databases in real-time, our system enables organizations to rapidly identify, prioritize, and remediate risks. Our case study demonstrates a significant reduction in the mean time to patch critical vulnerabilities.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the efficacy of employing deep learning models for network intrusion detection in enterprise environments. Traditional signature-based systems fail to identify novel and zero-day attacks, creating significant security gaps. We propose a hybrid model combining a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for spatial feature extraction with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network for temporal analysis of network traffic data. Tested against the CIC-IDS2017 dataset, our model demonstrates a 99.4% detection accuracy with a low false-positive rate, outperforming existing standalone deep learning and machine learning approaches. The results suggest that hybrid deep learning architectures offer a robust and adaptive solution for next-generation security operations.
label: AI

text: The human element remains a critical vulnerability in organizational security, with phishing attacks serving as a primary initial access vector. This study evaluates the long-term effectiveness of gamified security awareness training compared to traditional, compliance-focused modules. Through a 12-month longitudinal study involving 5,000 employees across two groups, we measured susceptibility via simulated phishing campaigns. The results indicate that the gamified cohort exhibited a 65% sustained reduction in click-rates, whereas the traditional group showed only a 20% initial reduction that degraded over time. We conclude that interactive, engaging training methodologies foster superior knowledge retention and behavioral change.
label: AI

text: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a vast and insecure attack surface. Due to severe resource constraints, traditional cryptographic solutions are often infeasible for these endpoints. This paper introduces a lightweight, hardware-based authentication protocol utilizing Physically Unclonable Functions (PUFs) to establish a unique and unclonable device identity. Our protocol minimizes computational overhead and power consumption while providing strong resistance against spoofing and replay attacks. An implementation on an ARM Cortex-M4 microcontroller demonstrates a 70% reduction in energy consumption per authentication cycle compared to standard ECC-based methods, presenting a viable security primitive for constrained IoT ecosystems.
label: AI

text: The impending advent of fault-tolerant quantum computers threatens to break currently deployed public-key cryptography, necessitating a transition to post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) standards. This paper presents a comparative performance analysis of three leading PQC signature schemes—CRYSTALS-Dilithium (lattice-based), SPHINCS+ (hash-based), and Classic McEliece (code-based)—on common server and embedded hardware. We benchmark key generation, signing, and verification speeds, as well as signature and key sizes. Our findings reveal critical trade-offs: while lattice-based schemes offer a strong balance of performance and size, hash-based schemes provide robust security assumptions at the cost of significantly larger signatures and slower signing operations.
label: AI

text: Attribution of state-sponsored cyber operations is a complex process hindered by technical obfuscation and geopolitical ambiguity. This research proposes a multi-layered analytical framework that moves beyond purely technical indicators of compromise (IoCs). Our model integrates tactical analysis of TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) with strategic assessment of geopolitical intent and victimology, using a Bayesian inference network to weigh evidence. Applying this framework to historical case studies demonstrates an increased confidence level in attribution and a more nuanced understanding of adversary motives. This holistic approach provides a more rigorous and defensible methodology for intelligence analysts and policymakers navigating cyber conflict.
label: AI

text: This study evaluates the sources of uncertainty in long-term climate projections by analyzing the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6 (CMIP6) multi-model ensemble. We partition total variance in global mean temperature projections into three components: internal variability, inter-model differences, and scenario uncertainty. Our findings indicate that while internal variability dominates on decadal timescales, inter-model uncertainty is the primary contributor to projection spread by mid-century. However, by 2100, scenario uncertainty, driven by different socio-economic pathways, becomes the largest source of variance. This underscores the dual necessity of improving model physics to reduce structural uncertainty and implementing decisive climate policy to constrain future emissions scenarios.
label: AI

text: Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs) are critical tools for exploring the interface between human activity and the climate system. This paper examines the role of socio-economic assumptions within IAMs by comparing climate outcomes under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs). We analyze how different narratives of future development—from sustainability-focused (SSP1) to fossil-fueled development (SSP5)—constrain the feasibility and cost of achieving the Paris Agreement targets. Results demonstrate that while technological pathways to 1.5°C exist across most SSPs, the required global policy coordination and economic transformation are substantially more challenging under scenarios characterized by high inequality and regional rivalry.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the fidelity of Earth System Models (ESMs) in simulating critical climate tipping points. We focus on the representation of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and its response to Greenland ice sheet meltwater forcing. A comparative analysis of leading ESMs reveals that while most models project a weakening of the AMOC under high-emissions scenarios, few exhibit the abrupt, non-linear collapse dynamics suggested by paleoclimatic evidence. This discrepancy is attributed to coarse ocean resolution and inadequate parameterization of key feedback mechanisms, suggesting that current model ensembles may underestimate the risk of rapid, high-impact climate shifts.
label: AI

text: To enhance the utility of global climate models (GCMs) for regional impact assessment, downscaling techniques are essential. This work compares the performance of statistical downscaling (SD) and dynamical downscaling via a Regional Climate Model (RCM) for projecting changes in extreme precipitation over a complex topographical region. While the RCM provides a more physically consistent representation of atmospheric processes, our results show that a well-calibrated SD method can reproduce key precipitation metrics with significantly lower computational cost. The choice of method involves a trade-off between physical fidelity and efficiency, with hybrid approaches offering a promising path forward for robust local-scale projections.
label: AI

text: We assess the performance of state-of-the-art climate models by hindcasting the 20th-century climate and comparing simulations against a comprehensive observational dataset. The analysis focuses on key metrics including global surface temperature trends, sea-ice extent, and patterns of ocean heat uptake. While models successfully reproduce the observed long-term warming trend when driven by historical forcings, significant biases persist in regional temperature distribution and precipitation patterns. Furthermore, a subset of high-sensitivity models overestimates historical warming, highlighting the ongoing challenge of constraining climate sensitivity and improving the accuracy of regional projections through better observational constraints and process understanding.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the atmospheric composition of the sub-Neptune exoplanet K2-18b using transit spectroscopy data from the James Webb Space Telescope. We employ advanced atmospheric retrieval techniques to model the planet's transmission spectrum, focusing on the potential presence of biogenic gases. Our analysis reveals robust detections of methane and carbon dioxide, but finds no statistically significant evidence for dimethyl sulfide, a gas proposed as a potential biosignature. The results suggest K2-18b may possess a hydrogen-rich atmosphere overlying a water ocean, a "Hycean" world. However, the lack of definitive biosignatures underscores the need for further observations to characterize this compelling exoplanetary environment.
label: AI

text: We present results from numerical relativity simulations of binary black hole mergers where one or both components possess significant natal spin misaligned with the orbital angular momentum. These precessing systems generate complex gravitational wave signals characterized by strong amplitude and frequency modulation. Our simulations demonstrate that the signal's morphology, particularly during the late inspiral and merger phases, is a sensitive probe of the individual black hole spins and the degree of precession. These high-fidelity waveform models are essential for accurately inferring source parameters from detections by LIGO, Virgo, and KAGRA, and for testing the predictions of general relativity in the strong-field regime.
label: AI

text: We use the spatial distribution and clustering of galaxies from the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) to measure the scale of Baryon Acoustic Oscillations (BAO) at multiple redshifts. The BAO feature provides a standard ruler to map the expansion history of the universe. Our measurements, spanning redshifts from z=0.1 to z=2.1, are combined with data from the cosmic microwave background to constrain cosmological parameters. We find the dark energy equation-of-state parameter, w, to be -1.026 ± 0.031, a result fully consistent with the cosmological constant model and representing one of the tightest constraints on the nature of dark energy to date.
label: AI

text: The origin of fast radio bursts (FRBs) remains one of the greatest mysteries in modern astrophysics. We present a multi-wavelength analysis of a repeating FRB source, FRB 20201124A, localized to a nearby spiral galaxy. Using simultaneous radio, X-ray, and optical observations, we place stringent limits on any associated persistent or transient emission. While the radio bursts exhibit complex temporal and spectral structure, we find no correlated variability at higher energies. This non-detection rules out several progenitor models involving cataclysmic events and constrains the emission mechanisms for models involving magnetars, favoring processes internal to the magnetosphere over those driven by external relativistic shocks.
label: AI

text: We investigate the chemical evolution of the Milky Way's stellar halo using high-resolution spectra of metal-poor stars. Our sample includes stars identified as members of distinct accreted dwarf galaxies based on their kinematic properties. We find significant chemical differences, particularly in alpha-element to iron ratios ([α/Fe]), between stars from different progenitor galaxies. These unique chemical abundance patterns, or "tags," persist long after the galaxies have been tidally disrupted. This work demonstrates that chemical tagging is a powerful tool for galactic archaeology, enabling us to reconstruct the merger history of our galaxy and understand the diverse star-forming environments of its building blocks.
label: AI

text: This research addresses the "black box" problem in deep neural networks for medical diagnostics. We propose a novel framework that integrates Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) with a convolutional neural network trained for melanoma detection from dermoscopic images. The model not only achieves a classification accuracy of 96.4% but also produces high-resolution saliency maps that highlight the specific lesion features influencing its predictions. A double-blind study with three dermatologists confirmed that these visual explanations strongly correlate with established clinical indicators, demonstrating the framework's potential to increase clinician trust, improve diagnostic workflow, and serve as a valuable tool for medical training.
label: AI

text: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training on decentralized data without compromising user privacy. However, its performance degrades significantly under statistical heterogeneity, where data distributions vary across clients (non-IID data). This paper introduces a novel aggregation algorithm, Clustered Federated Averaging (CFA), which dynamically groups clients based on the cosine similarity of their gradient updates. By performing intra-cluster model averaging before a weighted global aggregation, CFA mitigates the conflicting updates from disparate clients. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and FEMNIST datasets show that CFA improves convergence speed and achieves up to a 7% higher final accuracy compared to standard FedAvg in highly skewed data environments.
label: AI

text: We explore the application of deep reinforcement learning (RL) for autonomous traffic signal control in complex urban intersections. Our approach models a multi-agent system where each traffic signal is an independent agent learning a cooperative policy to minimize vehicle queue length and wait times. Using a Double Dueling Deep Q-Network (D3QN), agents process local traffic state information from simulated camera feeds. The proposed system demonstrates a 35% reduction in average vehicle delay and a 22% increase in network throughput compared to traditional fixed-time controllers and actuated signal systems in a high-fidelity SUMO simulation, showcasing its adaptability to dynamic traffic patterns.
label: AI

text: The discovery of novel materials with targeted properties is a computationally intensive and expensive process. This work presents a variational autoencoder (VAE) architecture for the inverse design of crystalline materials. By learning a continuous latent representation of stable crystal structures from the Materials Project database, our model can generate new, chemically valid structures by sampling from this latent space. We demonstrate the ability to guide generation toward specific target properties, such as high bulk modulus, by incorporating a property prediction network into the training loop. Several generated candidate structures are predicted by DFT calculations to be thermodynamically stable and exhibit superior properties.
label: AI

text: Large language models (LLMs) often perpetuate and amplify societal biases present in their training data. This paper investigates the effectiveness of instruction-tuning for mitigating gender bias in downstream NLP tasks. We create a curated dataset of instruction-response pairs designed to explicitly teach the model principles of gender-neutral and equitable language use. By fine-tuning a pre-trained LLM on this dataset, we significantly reduce stereotypical associations in open-ended generation and co-reference resolution tasks, as measured by the CrowS-Pairs and WinoBias benchmarks. Our results indicate that targeted instruction-tuning is a more effective and data-efficient debiasing strategy than purely adversarial methods.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the structural uncertainty within the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) ensemble. While multi-model ensembles are crucial for quantifying the range of potential climate futures, significant divergence persists in key metrics like climate sensitivity and regional precipitation patterns. We analyze the underlying causes of this divergence by comparing parameterization schemes for unresolved physical processes, particularly cloud microphysics and aerosol-cloud interactions. Our findings indicate that differences in representing these sub-grid-scale phenomena account for a substantial portion of inter-model variance. We argue that reducing this structural uncertainty requires a combined approach of targeted high-resolution modeling and improved observational constraints on critical feedback mechanisms.
label: AI

text: The accurate representation of cryospheric dynamics remains a critical challenge for global climate models, particularly concerning projections of sea-level rise. This paper examines the implementation of advanced ice sheet models for Greenland and Antarctica, focusing on their coupling with ocean and atmospheric components. We assess model performance in simulating key processes such as basal melt from ocean warming, surface mass balance, and ice calving dynamics. Results show that models incorporating dynamic ice-ocean interactions and fracture mechanics project a significantly faster and potentially non-linear contribution to sea-level rise this century, highlighting the urgent need to resolve these processes to constrain high-end risk scenarios.
label: AI

text: Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs) bridge the gap between physical climate science and socio-economic analysis, providing essential tools for policy evaluation. This research explores the climate outcomes resulting from different Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs). By forcing a general circulation model with emissions scenarios derived from these pathways, we analyze the distinct climate trajectories associated with varying levels of global cooperation, technological development, and mitigation effort. The results demonstrate that socio-economic choices in the coming decades are the dominant determinant of long-term climate change, with divergent pathways leading to worlds that differ by several degrees in global mean temperature by 2100.
label: AI

text: Downscaling techniques are essential for translating coarse-resolution global climate model (GCM) outputs into policy-relevant regional information. This work compares the efficacy of statistical and dynamical downscaling methods for projecting changes in extreme precipitation events in a complex topographical region. While statistical methods offer computational efficiency, dynamical downscaling using a Regional Climate Model (RCM) better captures localized convective processes and orographic effects. Our analysis reveals that the choice of downscaling method significantly influences the projected intensity and frequency of future flood-risk events, underscoring the importance of selecting an appropriate technique for specific climate impact assessments and adaptation planning.
label: AI

text: Cloud feedbacks constitute the largest source of uncertainty in modern climate models. This study investigates the representation of low-level marine stratocumulus clouds, which exert a strong global cooling effect. Using a suite of global models, we demonstrate a persistent link between a model’s baseline simulation of these clouds in the present climate and the magnitude of its positive low-cloud feedback under warming. Models that poorly represent the spatial extent and radiative properties of these clouds tend to project a stronger reduction in their coverage in a warmer world, leading to a higher climate sensitivity. This emphasizes that improving the simulation of contemporary cloud regimes is paramount for constraining future warming projections.
label: AI

text: This study introduces a novel algorithm, Graph-VF, for the accurate detection of low-frequency structural variants (SVs) from next-generation sequencing data. Conventional methods often fail to identify complex SVs or produce high false-positive rates in heterogeneous samples, such as tumors. Graph-VF constructs a de Bruijn graph from discordant read-pairs and split-reads, enabling the robust assembly of variant-supporting contigs. By integrating read depth and mapping quality into a probabilistic scoring model, our approach significantly improves sensitivity and specificity over existing tools. We demonstrate its superior performance on both simulated and clinical cancer datasets, highlighting its potential for advancing precision oncology.
label: AI

text: We address the challenge of protein function prediction from amino acid sequence using a deep learning framework that bypasses reliance on homology. Our model, ProtAttend, employs an attention-based neural network to learn long-range dependencies and identify functionally critical motifs directly from raw sequence data. Trained on a comprehensive database of annotated proteins, ProtAttend effectively assigns Gene Ontology (GO) terms across molecular function, biological process, and cellular component domains. When benchmarked against established sequence-alignment-based methods and other machine learning approaches, our model demonstrates state-of-the-art accuracy, particularly for proteins with no close homologs, thereby narrowing the sequence-function gap.
label: AI

text: The analysis of microbial communities through shotgun metagenomics is often hampered by the difficulty of assembling and binning genomes from complex mixtures. This work presents MetaCluster-AI, an unsupervised machine learning pipeline for improved metagenome-assembled genome (MAG) recovery. It integrates sequence composition features (k-mer frequencies) with differential coverage information across multiple samples into a variational autoencoder. This latent space representation facilitates more distinct clustering of contigs belonging to individual species. Applied to human gut microbiome datasets, MetaCluster-AI recovers a higher number of high-quality MAGs with lower contamination compared to current leading methods, enabling deeper insight into microbial ecology.
label: AI

text: Understanding gene regulation requires mapping transcription factor binding sites (TFBS), a task complicated by the degeneracy of binding motifs. We developed a multi-omics integration method that combines ATAC-seq data for chromatin accessibility with RNA-seq expression data to refine TFBS predictions. Our Bayesian statistical framework models the joint probability of a binding event given both a motif match and evidence of local regulatory activity. This approach drastically reduces false-positive predictions inherent in motif scanning alone. By applying this model to a developmental biology dataset, we successfully identified novel regulatory interactions and constructed more accurate gene regulatory networks driving cellular differentiation.
label: AI

text: Computational drug discovery relies heavily on accurate protein-ligand docking and binding affinity prediction. We present a novel scoring function based on a graph convolutional network (GCN) that learns intricate atomic interaction patterns from 3D structural data. Unlike traditional physics-based scoring functions, our GCN model is trained end-to-end on a large dataset of experimentally determined protein-ligand complexes and their affinities. This data-driven approach allows it to capture subtle non-covalent interactions and solvation effects more effectively. In large-scale virtual screening benchmarks, our GCN-based scorer consistently outperforms classical and other machine learning methods in identifying potent binders, accelerating hit identification.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the vulnerability of machine learning-based malware detectors to adversarial evasion techniques. We propose a framework utilizing Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to systematically generate polymorphic malware variants capable of bypassing both static and dynamic classifiers. By manipulating feature distributions while preserving malicious functionality, our method demonstrates a significant reduction in detection efficacy across several leading models. The findings reveal a critical arms race between AI-driven defense and offense, underscoring the necessity for robust adversarial training and anomaly detection protocols to fortify next-generation security systems against sophisticated, adaptive threats.
label: AI

text: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices introduces unique security challenges due to inherent resource constraints. This paper addresses the critical gap in secure, lightweight communication protocols for low-power, computationally limited endpoints. We design and implement a novel, hybrid cryptographic scheme that leverages elliptic-curve cryptography for efficient key exchange and a symmetric stream cipher optimized for minimal processing overhead. Empirical analysis conducted on representative microcontroller-based hardware demonstrates a significant reduction in energy consumption and latency compared to traditional security protocols, providing a viable pathway for achieving end-to-end security in large-scale IoT deployments.
label: AI

text: This study evaluates the comparative efficacy of different security awareness training methodologies in mitigating phishing susceptibility. We conducted a longitudinal experiment within a corporate environment, exposing distinct employee cohorts to traditional, simulation-based, and gamified training modules. Pre- and post-intervention susceptibility was measured using controlled phishing campaigns, tracking click rates and reporting behavior. Our results indicate that the gamified intervention yielded a statistically significant reduction in vulnerability and a higher incidence of threat reporting. These findings suggest that incorporating principles of engagement and competition can substantially improve the effectiveness of human-centric security controls.
label: AI

text: Attribution of state-sponsored cyber-attacks remains a persistent challenge, hindering effective policy and legal responses. This research examines the intersection of technical forensics and international relations by analyzing the strategic use of ambiguity in recent Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) campaigns. Through a qualitative analysis of attack vectors, malware signatures, and command-and-control infrastructure, we identify sophisticated obfuscation techniques designed to create plausible deniability. We argue that this intentional ambiguity subverts traditional norms of state responsibility, concluding that robust international frameworks for cyber-accountability require a new consensus that moves beyond purely technical proof toward a more holistic, context-aware model.
label: AI

text: The dissolution of the traditional network perimeter necessitates a paradigm shift from implicit trust to a Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA). This paper investigates the practical implementation and security efficacy of ZTA principles in a complex, hybrid-cloud enterprise environment. We developed a formal model integrating micro-segmentation, identity-centric controls, and continuous multi-factor authentication. Its performance was benchmarked against a legacy perimeter-based model through a series of simulated red-team exercises targeting lateral movement and data exfiltration. The ZTA model demonstrated a profound reduction in attack surface and successfully mitigated privilege escalation vectors, affirming its superiority in preventing and containing breaches.
label: AI

text: This study presents a novel algorithm for the structural alignment of proteins, leveraging deep learning to identify evolutionarily conserved topological features. Unlike traditional methods reliant on sequence homology or secondary structure matching, our approach employs a graph convolutional network trained on a vast dataset of protein domains from the CATH database. The model learns to generate a fixed-size vector embedding for each protein that is invariant to rotation and translation. We demonstrate that alignments derived from cosine similarity in this embedding space achieve superior accuracy and computational efficiency, particularly for proteins with low sequence identity but similar folds, offering a powerful new tool for functional annotation.
label: AI

text: Identifying driver mutations from tumor sequencing data is complicated by extensive passenger mutations and intra-tumor heterogeneity. We developed a network-based method that integrates somatic mutation data with a human protein-protein interaction network. By applying a modified PageRank algorithm, our tool, MutRank, prioritizes genes whose mutations are likely to have a significant disruptive impact on cellular signaling pathways. When validated against the COSMIC database and functional screen data, MutRank outperformed existing methods based on mutation frequency alone, successfully identifying both known cancer drivers and novel candidate genes, thereby providing a more systems-level view of oncogenesis.
label: AI

text: The analysis of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) data is hampered by high dimensionality and technical noise. We introduce a new computational pipeline for cell type identification that combines a variational autoencoder for non-linear dimension reduction with a self-supervised clustering algorithm. This approach effectively learns a robust latent representation of the cellular manifold, mitigating the effects of dropout events. When benchmarked on multiple public scRNA-seq datasets, our method demonstrated enhanced accuracy in resolving subtle cell subtypes and identifying rare cell populations compared to standard workflows like Seurat and Scanpy, facilitating a more nuanced understanding of cellular heterogeneity.
label: AI

text: Metagenomic analysis is crucial for understanding microbial community function, yet gene prediction in short, fragmented sequencing reads remains a significant challenge. This paper describes MetaGene-AI, a deep learning model utilizing a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network to predict protein-coding regions directly from raw metagenomic reads. Trained on a diverse set of prokaryotic genomes, the model effectively learns sequence composition and codon usage patterns. MetaGene-AI shows a marked improvement in both sensitivity and specificity over existing ab initio predictors, especially on reads shorter than 200 bp, enabling more comprehensive functional profiling of complex microbiomes.
label: AI

text: Predicting the effects of non-synonymous single nucleotide variants (nsSNVs) on protein stability and function is a central challenge in medical genetics. We developed a machine learning model, PolyVariant-3D, that integrates sequence-based features with structural information derived from protein models. The model uses a gradient boosting framework trained on a curated set of thousands of experimentally characterized mutations. Crucially, it incorporates features describing changes in local atomic environments and residue interaction networks. PolyVariant-3D achieves state-of-the-art performance in distinguishing pathogenic from benign variants, offering clinicians and researchers a more accurate tool for variant interpretation.
label: AI

text: Earth System Models (ESMs) represent the pinnacle of climate modeling, integrating biogeochemical cycles with the physical components of General Circulation Models. Unlike earlier models focused solely on physics, ESMs simulate the complex interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, land, and cryosphere, and crucial element cycles like carbon and nitrogen. This holistic approach allows for the investigation of critical feedback mechanisms, such as carbon cycle responses to warming or changes in ocean acidification. By incorporating these earth system dynamics, ESMs provide a more comprehensive tool for projecting long-term climate change under various emission scenarios, forming the scientific backbone of reports by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
label: AI

text: A fundamental challenge in climate projection is quantifying and managing model uncertainty. This uncertainty arises from three primary sources: initial condition sensitivity, structural differences between models, and the parameterization of sub-grid-scale processes. To address this, the climate science community employs multi-model ensembles (MMEs), such as those in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP). By analyzing the range of outcomes from a diverse suite of independently developed models, researchers can generate probabilistic forecasts and assess the robustness of projected changes. This ensemble approach provides a more realistic appraisal of potential climate futures and is essential for risk-based adaptation and mitigation planning.
label: AI

text: Global Climate Models (GCMs) operate at coarse spatial resolutions, often hundreds of kilometers, which limits their direct applicability for local impact assessments. Downscaling techniques bridge this gap by translating large-scale climate projections into high-resolution information. This is achieved through two primary methods: dynamical downscaling, which uses high-resolution Regional Climate Models (RCMs) driven by GCM boundary conditions, and statistical downscaling, which establishes empirical relationships between large-scale predictors and local climate variables. While computationally expensive, dynamical methods provide physically consistent outputs, whereas statistical methods are more flexible. Both are vital for informing regional adaptation strategies in sectors like agriculture, water resource management, and urban planning.
label: AI

text: Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs) are a critical class of models that couple the biophysical climate system with human socio-economic systems. They explore the complex feedback loops between climate change, economic activity, land use, energy technologies, and global population dynamics. By simulating various policy interventions and socio-economic pathways (SSPs), IAMs provide insights into the potential costs, benefits, and feasibility of different mitigation and adaptation strategies. While they do not produce detailed physical climate projections, their strength lies in evaluating the systemic transformations required to achieve climate targets, making them instrumental in shaping international climate policy and understanding the human dimensions of climate change.
label: AI

text: The integration of machine learning (ML) is rapidly transforming the landscape of climate modeling. These data-driven techniques are being employed to improve computationally expensive sub-grid parameterization schemes, accelerate model simulations through the creation of statistical emulators, and identify complex patterns and precursors to extreme events in large model datasets. Furthermore, hybrid models that combine physics-based cores with ML components are emerging as a promising avenue for enhancing predictive skill while retaining physical consistency. This fusion of traditional numerical modeling with artificial intelligence promises to address long-standing challenges, enabling higher-resolution projections and more robust uncertainty quantification for future climate scenarios.
label: AI

text: This research investigates the psychological mechanisms and consequences of anthropomorphism in human-AI interaction. While attributing human-like qualities to AI agents can enhance user engagement, trust, and usability, our findings indicate significant risks. We explored how design cues, such as conversational language and personified avatars, foster parasocial relationships, leading to potential emotional dependency and over-disclosure of sensitive data. This study argues that the perceived intentionality in AI systems can blur the user's understanding of the technology's mechanistic nature. We conclude that an ethical design framework is crucial to mitigate these vulnerabilities and foster psychologically healthy long-term interactions.
label: AI

text: This paper examines the perpetuation of human cognitive biases through artificial intelligence systems. We posit that AI, trained on vast datasets of human behavior, not only inherits biases such as confirmation bias and stereotyping but also amplifies them through its operational logic. Our analysis reveals how interactions with biased AI in domains like recruitment and content curation can create a psychological feedback loop, reinforcing a user's pre-existing heuristics and worldviews. This phenomenon, which we term 'algorithmic confirmation,' poses a significant challenge to objective decision-making. We advocate for a psychological-forensic approach to AI auditing, focusing on mitigating the system's capacity to exploit human cognitive vulnerabilities.
label: AI

text: This study explores the impact of pervasive AI on the formation and maintenance of the self-concept. Through an analysis of personalization algorithms and generative AI tools, we argue that constant algorithmic curation fosters a 'scaffolded self,' where personal identity is increasingly shaped by external, machine-driven suggestions rather than internal exploration. We found that over-reliance on AI for creative and decisional tasks correlates with a diminished sense of agency and self-efficacy. The blurring boundary between innate and machine-augmented cognition presents a novel challenge for psychological theories of identity, demanding new frameworks to understand autonomy in the digital age.
label: AI

text: The proliferation of AI-driven chatbots as mental health tools necessitates a critical psychological evaluation. This research examines the efficacy and ethical implications of these digital therapeutics. Our findings indicate that while AI agents can effectively deliver structured interventions, such as those based on cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), they fundamentally lack the capacity for genuine therapeutic alliance and relational depth, key predictors of positive clinical outcomes. We explore the paradox where the AI's simulation of empathy can reduce stigma and encourage disclosure, yet concurrently create a false sense of security that may delay or prevent individuals from seeking necessary human-led care.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the extent to which humans apply Theory of Mind (ToM)—the ability to attribute mental states to others—to artificial intelligence. Using a series of behavioral experiments and neuroimaging data, we demonstrate that while interacting with sophisticated AI agents, individuals recruit cognitive mechanisms associated with ToM. However, the neural activation patterns are distinct from those observed during human-human social cognition. We propose the concept of a 'synthetic ToM,' a modified heuristic for inferring goals and 'beliefs' in non-conscious agents. This framework helps explain the nuances of trust, collaboration, and misunderstanding in human-AI partnerships.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the application of adaptive filtering for real-time acoustic noise cancellation in communication headsets. A normalized least mean squares (NLMS) algorithm is implemented on a low-power digital signal processor to model the noise path and generate an anti-noise signal. The system's performance is evaluated in various noisy environments, including simulated aircraft cockpit and factory floor conditions. We analyze the convergence rate of the adaptive filter and the achieved noise reduction, measured in decibels. Results indicate that the NLMS algorithm provides a robust and computationally efficient solution, achieving an average of 15-20 dB of attenuation across the speech frequency band, significantly improving speech intelligibility.
label: AI

text: Compressed sensing (CS) theory is applied to the challenge of accelerated data acquisition in biomedical imaging, specifically for electrocardiography (ECG) signals. By leveraging the inherent sparsity of the ECG signal in the wavelet domain, we demonstrate that a clinically useful signal can be accurately reconstructed from a small number of non-uniform samples, far below the Nyquist rate. This work compares the reconstruction fidelity of various L1-norm minimization algorithms, including basis pursuit and iterative hard thresholding. The proposed sub-Nyquist sampling and reconstruction framework has the potential to dramatically reduce data storage requirements and power consumption in wearable health monitoring devices without compromising diagnostic quality.
label: AI

text: This paper introduces a novel method for image denoising based on multi-resolution analysis using the stationary wavelet transform (SWT). Unlike the traditional discrete wavelet transform, the SWT is shift-invariant, which mitigates the introduction of visual artifacts during signal reconstruction. Noise is suppressed by applying a bivariate shrinkage function to the wavelet coefficients, which exploits the statistical dependencies between a coefficient and its parent. Quantitative comparisons against standard Wiener filtering and conventional wavelet thresholding show our method yields superior performance in terms of Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) and Structural Similarity Index (SSIM), particularly in preserving fine textures and sharp edges.
label: AI

text: We explore the use of deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for automatic modulation classification (AMC) in cognitive radio systems. The proposed model directly processes the in-phase and quadrature (I/Q) components of the raw signal as a two-channel input, learning discriminative features without manual feature engineering. The network architecture is optimized for robustness against channel impairments like multipath fading and carrier frequency offset. Trained on a large synthetic dataset, the classifier achieves over 90% accuracy at signal-to-noise ratios above 5 dB for a set of common digital and analog modulations, outperforming traditional feature-based methods and demonstrating viability for real-world spectrum sensing applications.
label: AI

text: This research addresses the problem of blind source separation (BSS) in convolutive audio mixtures using Independent Component Analysis (ICA) in the frequency domain. By applying the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT), the convolutive mixing problem in the time domain is approximated as a series of instantaneous complex-valued mixing problems in each frequency bin. We employ the FastICA algorithm to estimate the unmixing matrix for each bin, addressing the permutation and scaling ambiguities inherent to this approach. The proposed method demonstrates effective separation of two speech sources recorded in a reverberant room, significantly improving the Signal-to-Interference Ratio (SIR) of the recovered signals.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the application of deep reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize traffic signal control in complex urban networks. We propose a multi-agent RL framework where each intersection is managed by an independent agent that learns a control policy through local observations of traffic flow and communication with neighboring agents. Using a high-fidelity traffic simulation, our approach demonstrates a significant reduction in average vehicle delay and queue lengths compared to traditional fixed-time controllers and isolated adaptive methods. The results indicate that decentralized, cooperative learning strategies can achieve near-optimal network-wide performance, offering a scalable and robust solution for dynamic urban traffic management.
label: AI

text: The "black box" nature of complex neural networks is a significant barrier to their adoption in high-stakes domains such as medical diagnostics. This research introduces a novel post-hoc explainability method, Concept-Attribution Mapping (CAM), designed to interpret model decisions in terms of clinically meaningful concepts. By analyzing a convolutional neural network trained on radiological images, CAM generates visual explanations that highlight not only salient pixel regions but also the high-level pathological features the model associates with its prediction. Our evaluation shows that CAM provides more intuitive and actionable insights for clinicians than existing saliency-based techniques, fostering greater trust and facilitating model debugging.
label: AI

text: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training on decentralized data without compromising user privacy. However, statistical heterogeneity across client data (non-IID data) can severely degrade model performance and convergence speed. We present a novel aggregation algorithm, FedClust, which clusters clients based on the similarity of their model updates. A central server then maintains and aggregates distinct models for each cluster. Experiments on benchmark non-IID datasets show that FedClust significantly outperforms standard algorithms like FedAvg, achieving faster convergence and higher final model accuracy by mitigating the negative impacts of client drift and creating more personalized model groups.
label: AI

text: This work explores the use of unsupervised learning for anomaly detection in large-scale astronomical surveys. We employ a variational autoencoder (VAE) trained on millions of stellar spectra to learn a compact, low-dimensional representation of typical stellar objects. Objects that cannot be accurately reconstructed from this latent space are flagged as anomalous. Applying this technique to data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, our method successfully rediscovered known classes of peculiar stars and identified a cohort of previously unclassified candidates with highly unusual spectral features, demonstrating the power of unsupervised methods for hypothesis-free scientific discovery in vast datasets.
label: AI

text: We investigate the vulnerability of natural language processing models to adversarial attacks that use semantically equivalent paraphrases. While traditional attacks often rely on character-level or word-level perturbations that can be syntactically awkward, our method utilizes a generative model to produce fluent, contextually appropriate paraphrases designed to fool a target classifier. We demonstrate that state-of-the-art sentiment analysis and toxicity detection models are highly susceptible to these attacks, with success rates exceeding 85% while maintaining high semantic similarity and fluency as judged by human evaluators. These findings highlight a critical robustness gap in current NLP systems.
label: AI

text: We present high-fidelity transmission spectra of the sub-Neptune exoplanet K2-18 b from the James Webb Space Telescope, aimed at characterizing its atmospheric composition. Our analysis reveals statistically significant detections of methane (CH₄) and carbon dioxide (CO₂) while placing a firm upper limit on the abundance of ammonia (NH₃). This chemical inventory, particularly the presence of carbon-bearing molecules alongside a lack of ammonia, is consistent with theoretical models of a Hycean world—a temperate planet with a global water ocean beneath a hydrogen-rich atmosphere. While this composition is not a definitive biosignature, it supports the potential habitability of K2-18 b and warrants further investigation.
label: AI

text: The theory of cosmic inflation predicts a primordial background of gravitational waves that would imprint a unique B-mode polarization pattern on the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB). We analyze the latest data from the BICEP/Keck Array to search for this signal at large angular scales. After meticulously modeling and subtracting galactic foregrounds, primarily polarized dust and synchrotron emission, we find no statistically significant evidence for primordial B-modes. Our analysis places an updated upper limit on the tensor-to-scalar ratio of r < 0.036 at 95% confidence. This result further tightens constraints on large-field inflationary models and demonstrates the challenge of detecting this faint cosmological signal.
label: AI

text: The hierarchical model of galaxy formation posits that large galaxies like the Milky Way grow by accreting smaller satellite galaxies. We utilize astrometric and photometric data from Gaia DR3 to conduct a systematic search for stellar streams, the tidal remnants of these past mergers. By applying a novel stream-finding algorithm in a 6D phase-space, we identify five previously unknown, low-surface-brightness streams in the Galactic halo. We characterize their orbits, metallicities, and progenitor properties. One stream, named Cocytus, exhibits a highly eccentric and retrograde orbit, suggesting its progenitor was part of a major, ancient accretion event that significantly shaped the early Milky Way.
label: AI

text: The coincident detection of gravitational waves and electromagnetic radiation from compact object mergers provides a unique probe of extreme physics. We report on the multi-messenger observations of GW230529, a high-probability binary neutron star merger candidate detected by the LIGO-Virgo-Kagra network. The gravitational-wave signal constrains the system's chirp mass and tidal deformability, disfavoring extremely stiff equations of state for neutron star matter. A rapid, multi-wavelength electromagnetic follow-up campaign identified a short gamma-ray burst and a subsequent kilonova counterpart. The combined analysis of these signals provides robust constraints on the Hubble constant and the cosmic production rate of heavy r-process elements.
label: AI

text: The physical origin of Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), millisecond-duration extragalactic radio flashes, remains one of the greatest mysteries in modern astrophysics. A leading model posits that they are produced by magnetars—highly magnetized neutron stars. We present the simultaneous observation of an exceptionally luminous radio burst and a hard X-ray flare from the galactic magnetar SGR 1935+2154. The energy and duration of the radio burst are comparable to the faintest extragalactic FRBs. This unambiguous association provides the first direct, conclusive evidence that magnetar activity can generate the luminosities required for FRBs, strongly solidifying the magnetar-progenitor hypothesis.
label: AI

text: This paper argues that digital history is not merely a subfield but a fundamental epistemological challenge to the historical discipline. By employing computational methods such as text mining, network analysis, and data visualization, it shifts the scale of inquiry from the individual document to the massive corpus. This "distant reading" approach reveals patterns and structures invisible to traditional close-reading methodologies. However, this methodological shift necessitates a critical re-evaluation of historical evidence, argument, and interpretation. It forces historians to grapple with the nature of algorithmic "truth," the construction of datasets, and the need to blend quantitative findings with qualitative, hermeneutic analysis.
label: AI

text: Focusing on pedagogy and public engagement, this study examines how digital tools are transforming the teaching and dissemination of history. Interactive timelines, GIS-based story maps, and virtual reality reconstructions of historical sites move learners from passive recipients to active participants in historical inquiry. Furthermore, crowdsourcing projects, such as the transcription of archival documents or the tagging of historical photographs, foster a collaborative and democratized approach to historical production. We contend that these digital platforms not only enhance historical literacy but also help bridge the gap between academic scholarship and public memory, creating more inclusive and accessible historical narratives.
label: AI

text: The rise of "born-digital" sources—including emails, social media, and web archives—presents a critical challenge to traditional archival theory and practice. This research explores the profound issues of preservation, access, and authenticity posed by the ephemerality and technological dependency of digital objects. Unlike their analog counterparts, digital records are subject to bit rot, software obsolescence, and the loss of crucial contextual metadata. This analysis posits that historians must develop new critical frameworks for evaluating these sources, accounting for the influence of platform architecture and algorithmic curation on the historical record itself, thereby reconceptualizing the archive for the 21st century.
label: AI

text: This article provides a critical assessment of the limitations and inherent biases within digital history methodologies. While computational tools offer powerful analytical capabilities, they are not neutral; algorithms can amplify and re-inscribe the prejudices present in the historical data they process. Furthermore, the emphasis on quantifiable data often leads to the neglect of non-textual, ambiguous, or marginalized sources that resist easy digitization. We argue for a more self-reflexive digital practice that acknowledges the "digital divide" in skills and resources, questions the allure of techno-solutionism, and maintains a commitment to the ethical complexities and humanistic nuances central to historical interpretation.
label: AI

text: Spatial history, empowered by Geographic Information Systems (GIS), has emerged as a vital area of digital historical scholarship. This paper moves beyond a descriptive account of mapping projects to analyze how GIS functions as an analytical tool for constructing historical arguments. By layering diverse datasets—such as census records, property maps, and environmental data—historians can investigate the dynamic relationship between place and historical phenomena like urbanization, disease diffusion, or social conflict. We demonstrate that GIS transforms the map from a static illustration into a dynamic evidentiary platform, enabling spatio-temporal analysis that reveals previously hidden correlations and causalities in the past.
label: AI

text: This research presents a novel decentralized control algorithm for multi-robot swarms tasked with environmental monitoring. Inspired by entomological foraging patterns, our approach utilizes a probabilistic model for information sharing that requires only local, peer-to-peer communication. Each agent independently decides its exploration path based on a combination of personal sensor readings and aggregated data from its immediate neighbors. Simulations demonstrate that this method leads to emergent, globally efficient coverage of complex terrains, significantly outperforming centralized and standard frontier-based exploration strategies in both speed and robustness to individual agent failure. This scalable framework provides a foundation for deploying large-scale autonomous systems in search-and-rescue and precision agriculture.
label: AI

text: We investigate the challenge of sim-to-real transfer in deep reinforcement learning for dexterous robotic manipulation. Our work introduces a policy transfer method, Residual-Gated U-Net (RGU-Net), which learns to map simulated observations to their real-world counterparts. By training an auxiliary model on a small, unpaired dataset of real and simulated images, our agent can effectively leverage policies trained entirely in a randomized simulation environment. On a series of contact-rich tasks, including peg insertion and connector plugging, our method demonstrates a 40% improvement in success rate on the physical robot compared to direct policy transfer, enabling zero-shot performance on novel objects.
label: AI

text: This paper explores the role of communicated uncertainty in human-robot trust calibration during collaborative tasks. We conducted a human-subject experiment (N=72) where participants worked with a robotic assistant to identify targets under perceptual ambiguity. The robot communicated its confidence level for each recommendation using explicit verbal phrases and corresponding non-verbal cues. Results show that transparently communicating uncertainty enabled participants to more appropriately weigh the robot’s input, significantly improving joint team performance and reducing automation bias. These findings underscore the importance of designing robots that can convey their internal states to foster more effective and safer human-autonomy teaming.
label: AI

text: To address the limitations of rigid robots in unstructured environments, we have developed a bio-inspired soft robotic actuator based on dielectric elastomers. The actuator’s multi-layered, fiber-reinforced structure mimics the muscular hydrostat of an octopus arm, enabling multi-axis bending and elongation with high compliance. An integrated ionic liquid-based sensor network provides proprioceptive feedback on its configuration without compromising flexibility. Experimental validation shows the actuator can achieve precise position control while remaining inherently safe upon unexpected contact. This technology opens new possibilities for robots operating in close proximity to humans, particularly in assistive healthcare and delicate material handling.
label: AI

text: We propose a novel framework for Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) that tightly fuses data from an event-based camera and a sparse LiDAR sensor for robust navigation in perceptually degraded environments. By leveraging the high temporal resolution and high dynamic range of the event camera, our system effectively mitigates motion blur during aggressive maneuvers and maintains tracking in low-light conditions where traditional cameras fail. The asynchronous nature of both sensors is handled within a continuous-time factor graph optimization. On challenging public datasets, our approach demonstrates a marked improvement in trajectory accuracy and map consistency over state-of-the-art visual-inertial and LiDAR-inertial methods.
label: AI

text: This study investigates the epigenetic mechanisms governing neuronal lineage commitment from pluripotent stem cells. We demonstrate that the transcription factor PAX6 directly recruits the histone demethylase KDM7X to the promoters of key neurogenic genes. Using ChIP-seq and RNA-seq in a knockout cell line, we show that KDM7X specifically removes the repressive H3K27me3 mark, leading to transcriptional activation. Loss of KDM7X function results in a failure to exit the pluripotent state and initiate differentiation. Our findings elucidate a critical regulatory axis where a lineage-specifying factor commandeers a chromatin-modifying enzyme to enact a precise developmental program.
label: AI

text: The cellular decision between non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) and homologous recombination (HR) for repairing DNA double-strand breaks is critical for genomic stability. Here, we identify a novel factor, DSRF1, that functions as a molecular switch. Through immunoprecipitation and functional assays, we show that DSRF1 is phosphorylated by ATM kinase in S/G2 phases. This post-translational modification shifts its binding preference from the Ku70/80 complex to the BRCA1-A complex, effectively shunting repair toward high-fidelity HR. Cells deficient in DSRF1 exhibit elevated translocation rates and marked sensitization to PARP inhibitors, highlighting its role as a key regulator in pathway choice.
label: AI

text: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are increasingly recognized as critical regulators of gene expression, though their mechanisms remain elusive. This study characterizes a previously unannotated lncRNA, which we term ANCR-22 (Anti-Oncogenic Competing RNA-22). Utilizing RNA pulldown assays, we discovered that ANCR-22 functions as a molecular sponge for the oncomir miR-22. By sequestering miR-22, ANCR-22 de-represses the expression of the tumor suppressor PTEN. Ectopic expression of ANCR-22 in cancer cell lines leads to increased PTEN levels, G1 cell cycle arrest, and reduced proliferation, establishing a novel lncRNA-miRNA-mRNA regulatory axis in tumorigenesis.
label: AI

text: The accumulation of misfolded amyloid-beta (Aβ) oligomers is a central event in Alzheimer's disease pathology. Molecular chaperones play a crucial role in mitigating this proteotoxicity, but the structural basis of their interaction remains unclear. Using single-particle cryo-electron microscopy, we have determined the 2.8 Å structure of the human Hsp70 chaperone bound to a disease-relevant Aβ42 oligomer. The structure reveals that Hsp70’s substrate-binding domain engages a specific hydrophobic cleft on the oligomer surface, effectively capping the fibril-growing end. This interaction sterically hinders further monomer recruitment, providing a direct molecular mechanism for Hsp70’s anti-aggregation activity.
label: AI

text: The therapeutic potential of CRISPR-based base editors is hampered by concerns over off-target DNA modifications. To address this, we have engineered a novel high-fidelity adenine base editor (ABE-HF) by rationally mutating the deaminase domain to reduce its processivity on transiently unwound DNA. We employed unbiased genome-wide off-target detection assays and found that ABE-HF reduces off-target editing to undetectable levels in human cell lines, a >100-fold improvement over the parental enzyme. Importantly, on-target editing efficiency at multiple therapeutically relevant loci was maintained. This next-generation base editor provides a substantially safer tool for precision gene correction.
label: AI

text: This investigation explores the role of histone deacetylases (HDACs) in regulating cardiac hypertrophy. Using a murine model, we demonstrate that selective inhibition of Class I HDACs prevents pathological cardiac remodeling in response to pressure overload. Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing revealed that HDAC inhibition blocks the aberrant expression of fetal gene programs by maintaining histone H3 acetylation at their promoter regions. Furthermore, our results show that this epigenetic modulation preserves mitochondrial function and reduces fibrosis. These findings identify a specific epigenetic mechanism underlying heart failure progression and suggest that targeted HDAC inhibitors could represent a novel therapeutic avenue for treating hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
label: AI

text: The fidelity of DNA replication is paramount for genomic stability. This study elucidates the structural mechanism by which polymerase epsilon (Pol ε), the leading-strand DNA polymerase, achieves its high accuracy. Using cryo-electron microscopy, we captured high-resolution structures of Pol ε in complex with DNA at various stages of nucleotide incorporation. The structures reveal a highly selective active site and a unique "pre-insertion" checkpoint within the P-domain that scrutinizes the incoming nucleotide before catalysis.
